file_content.text: I hear the Dread Masters are on the loose once more. Well done.
The landing zone site remains secure.
That was a rare occasion. We had half their numbers and still handed them their heads!
Ruger must have been furious. I can only imagine the thrill of snuffing out his life.
I'll only be thrilled when this prison is wiped clean of the Republic.
This was just the beginning.
Then you won't have to wait long. With Ruger out of the picture, our landing zone's untouchable.
"Thrilling" doesn't begin to describe what it felt like to stick that lawman.
You don't know the half of it.
And as Ruger's screams fade, we know our landing zone won't be threatened again.
Ruger's dead. I save my excitement for payday.
Just another job.
You've more than earned it. With Ruger gone, no one can threaten our landing zone. Not even the incompetent warden.
Ruger was one more casualty of our war with the Republic. Nothing more.
Actually, I felt nothing.
I imagine your detachment served you well against Ruger. And with him gone, our landing zone's finally secure.
There's no thrill in murder.
Ruger's history. Now what?
I will fortify our landing zone and feed the riot.
I hear you spared Ruger. At least you managed to squeeze a ransom out of the poor warden. He sent this payment to you, with well wishes.
The warden wasn't particularly friendly when we parted ways.
Well wishes? I doubt that.
You ruined his prize lawman, turned his prison into a circus. I'm surprised he didn't send you a grenade.
I trust you didn't skim any off the top.
This better be everything.
I wouldn't dream of denying you your spoils. Not when you kicked Ruger off Belsavis for good.
Ruger didn't need to die.
I'll never understand that argument. But at least we can agree that with Ruger gone, our landing zone's finally secure.
If you'll excuse me, duty calls. I must re-establish contact with Commander Calum.
He'll be glad to hear how you handled the riots--and Ellis Ruger. You've served the Empire well.
Lord Medechas. Come in, Lord Medechas.
I am here, Commander Calum. What is your will?
Ellis Ruger was blocking our signal. Your men re-established contact once he fell, but I've heard nothing from our other operations groups.
Captain Vandorn must be reached. Our mission is still in jeopardy.
Leave this mission to me. Lord Medechas will guard the rear.
I'll find Captain Vandorn.
I give the orders. But yes--you are best suited to meet the lost operations group.
Secure the landing zone, Lord Medechas. And stay in constant contact. Commander Calum out.
I've defeated Ruger, the Republic's dealing with the riot. What's left?
Is there a new threat?
The Republic may be the least of our worries in this prison.
Lord Medechas is right. That's why he'll defend the landing zone against further Republic interference. You will perform the rendezvous.
Don't fret so much, Commander.
The Dread Masters will help us defeat the Republic. I'll stop worrying when they're free of Belsavis's chains.
Lord Medechas--secure the landing zone. You--rendezvous with our lost operations group. Do not delay.
Captain Vandorn was last seen in the high security wing. Find his camp, but be wary. The Republic is conducting strange experiments with the inmates there.
Don't delay. We can't give Ruger a chance to detect our attack.
Ruger is finally vulnerable. If you're ready, we can end his campaign and secure this landing zone for good.
Tell me where this lawman is, and our problems are over.
I'm ready.
Ruger and his men are in a guard station. He believes it's more secure than the main intake building.
How much resistance is Ruger packing?
What defenses are we facing?
He lacks his Crisis Response Unit, but the guard station will be full of veteran soldiers. Expect the worst.
Hurry before Ruger catches on.
Use the security key to drop their shields. My teams will cut off Ruger's backup. No one gets in, no one gets out.
We'll give you time to work. Just make sure Ruger doesn't escape.
I've been waiting to get my hands on Ellis Ruger.
He'll get what's coming.
His men know what to do in battle. Any shock we cause will wear off quickly.
A solid plan.
Prepare yourself. Just because Ruger hasn't risked himself before doesn't mean he's easy prey.
This is his stronghold. Bring everything you have, and every ally you trust. We will get no second chance.
What happens when Ruger and his men are captured or dead?
And once it's over?
Then it's done. The warden will have only stragglers to enforce his will. Our shuttles will be free to fly out anyone we desire.
But let's not speculate. Go to the guard station and strike at Ruger. We will be behind you.
It's done. I have the key to the security fields.
We must strike quickly, before word of Gholan's death spreads.
Secure Gholan's key, and Ellis Ruger will be exposed.
It's time someone ends Ruger's career. We've found a way to strike at him directly.
The only things keeping us from his throat are the force fields guarding his base. Luckily, a mad Devaronian prisoner--Gholan--has the key.
Gholan will surrender the key. He has no choice.
So we take it.
The Devaronian may see things differently.
This Devaronian just got out of prison. There must be a hundred things he'd take in trade.
Surely he'd take a deal.
We offered him a shuttle off-planet, weapons, aged Corellian brandy, even female companionship. Gholan turned everything down.
Don't tell me Ruger hid it under a rock outside his base.
How did Gholan get the key?
I don't know Gholan's methods. Only that he stole the key, and Ruger doesn't have a clue it's missing. Sadly, Gholan's less than cooperative.
I can get you your key... and the hand holding it.
Gholan's as good as dead.
I almost pity the poor Devaronian. But you should know--Gholan is not your average prisoner.
He knows the key's valuable. Plus he's trained in the Force, and highly violent. The Republic tried executing him four times.
That's when they shipped him to Belsavis. Now Gholan thinks he can't die. He's refusing to hand over the key to Ruger's guard station.
I will study his power in action as I kill him.
Interesting, but he will die.
What you do or learn is none of my affair. The key is what matters.
This Gholan may not fear death, but he'll soon beg for it.
I'll make him die painfully.
Save your torments for Ruger. This mission simply demands a quick kill and the key in our hand.
The Republic may have failed to kill Gholan, but I know tricks they don't.
I'll quiet him for good.
You've proved resourceful. Unfortunately, so has he.
I like killing indestructible people. It's worth the wait.
I can finish him.
If it's a challenge you want, you could do worse than this Devaronian.
Maybe Gholan will listen to me.
You can try talking to him, but he's more the rip-your-arms-off type. Be ready when you approach.
Where can I find him?
Gholan roams near the resettlement camps, in the open areas where wise inmates leave him alone.
Make your way there. The longer we delay, the more likely Ruger will change the lock frequency on the security fields.
There was only enough power to thaw the best prisoners.
We released the psychopaths. They'll show those rioters how to really fight.
I unleashed the worst murderers I could find.
The convicts were violent before. With psychopaths at the helm, there's no telling what crimes they'll commit. Ruger will not be pleased.
We unleashed the agitators. They'll whip this riot into shape.
I freed the agitators. They'll give these prisoners a purpose.
What those convicts lack in brutality they make up for in wits. And they've already organized a large-scale riot. Ruger will not be pleased.
He called to threaten me. He seemed unafraid.
I spoke with Ruger.
Ruger's tamed prisons before, even restored order to Coruscant's depths. It's time we end his career.
That lawman doesn't scare me.
Still, you shouldn't ignore him. Ruger's tamed the most violent, overcrowded prisons in the galaxy. And it's time we end his career.
You can worry about his mood swings. I won't.
I don't care for his feelings.
We can use his temper to our advantage. Infuriate Ruger, and he's bound to fall. But first we must remove his defenses.
Thaw out the most sadistic monsters you can. Fear is our ally.
Thanks to you, the inmates have turned from whipped dogs into predators.
Still, we need more convicts on our side. Turn this mob into an army, and the Republic will be permanently occupied.
An army begins with generals. We must provide the prisoners with the leadership they require.
There must be plenty of leadership material locked up here. Break them out, and put them to work.
Recruit prisoners to lead.
Exactly.
There's no way I'm commanding this herd of mynocks.
Don't look at me.
That would waste our time and your talent. Leaders already exist. We simply must wake them up.
Out with it.
There's a carbonite storage facility in the intake yards, full of frozen convicts.
Some were rebellion leaders. Others simply murdered every guard they found. We need both persuasions.
If this is so simple, why isn't it done already?
Why does this sound too easy?
We face a thinking opponent. I've proceeded as necessary.
Releasing them into the general population should prove entertaining.
Sounds sadistic. I like it.
Splendid. Though the unfreezing process won't be simple.
I know the revolutionary type. I've bagged a few.
I can see where this goes.
I suppose previous experience is a plus.
Can't we train the prisoners ourselves? You've already armed them.
Why do we need these people?
These prisoners are celebrities down here. They command loyalty and respect. Let them lead the riot while we keep this landing zone open.
Sounds fast and easy. Leave their rescue to me.
I'll thaw them out.
Excellent. I've taken measures to maximize the benefits of this operation.
Make it worth my time.
You'll be provided for. However, if my plan works, you may encounter some extra defenses.
Prisoner--what of your mission into the carbon gallery?
The Crisis Response Unit ambushed us! I got away. Only me.
Excellent. Ruger took the bait.
Now you can free the frozen prisoners and wipe out the Crisis Response Unit, all at once.
Who are these guards, exactly?
A Crisis Response Unit?
They train for everything--hostages, riots, Sith opponents. They slaughtered us.
Another word, inmate, and I'll throw you back in prison.
Ruger's men are dangerous, but don't let it give you pause.
Your trap just made my job more dangerous.
You've complicated things.
But the payoff will be considerable. Without his top men, Ruger must scramble to defend his station.
Then I will go.
Destroy the guards, and defrost the prisoners. They'll turn this riot into an organized army.
Then we'll have safe passage to extract the Dread Masters.
The warden droids are no more. I hope the rioters took note.
Have no fear. Thousands of prisoners already move against the droids.
More devotees follow your footsteps every minute. Many have died in the process, but that's normal.
Dismantling those droids wasn't the easiest thing I've ever done.
I hope you appreciate it.
I respect the effort involved. Each warden droid has the strength of dozens of prisoners.
All in a day's work.
Then I have a powerful ally indeed. The warden droids were meant to be the equal of twenty prisoners.
Minimum effort, maximum results, I see.
Let them kill each other.
They will occupy the guards' attention with little more energy on our part. A fine move.
The warden droids are easy to spot. Look for clouds of tear gas and writhing prisoners.
Welcome, my lord. I assumed Commander Calum sent you to help.
Welcome, agent. I take it Commander Calum sent you to lend us your talents.
Hunter... welcome. I take it Commander Calum conscripted your services.
Welcome, welcome. I knew Commander Calum would send assistance once we lost contact.
I'm Lord Medechas, leader of Operations Group Five. We started this riot by arming prisoners and pointing them at their Republic captors.
But our primary goal is to extract certain inmates held deep within the prison.
Commander Calum said they were Sith Lords.
Dread Masters, if I recall.
Correct. The Dread Masters.
What's the status of this riot?
How has the fighting been?
The violence is coming to a boil. But our primary orders are to free several Sith Lords known as the Dread Masters.
How do we free them?
It's complicated. The Sith we're after are known as the Dread Masters. They're held somewhere in Belsavis's most secure wing.
They can reach out through the Force and pierce their enemies with terror. Whole armadas surrender to them without firing a shot.
The Republic claimed the Dread Masters were killed in the last war. Returning them to the field would be a crowning achievement.
Why haven't you broken them out?
So go get them already.
The Republic evaded our forces and took the Dread Masters into the Deep Prison.
Do you have a fix on the Dread Masters' location?
Where are they now?
The Republic moved them into the Deep Prison. We've heard nothing since.
Sounds worthy of my efforts.
Free the Dread Masters and you'll find much to your advantage. Unfortunately, the Republic's moved them to the Deep Prison.
Meanwhile, the warden brought in a hardheaded offworld enforcer, Ellis Ruger. He's here to close our exit corridor.
If the Republic isn't stopped, they'll retake this landing zone. Without an exit, our prison break will fail.
Don't give an inch of ground to the Republic.
Then we hold the landing zone.
We're trying, but the prison guards aren't helping matters. They're hiding behind force fields, and they've just deployed mechanical peacekeepers.
I've held off army units. Prison guards will be like wading through dung.
I fear no soldiers.
Just the attitude we need to break them. They're cowering behind force fields, sending droids to do their dirty work.
You have prisoners rioting all over. Can the Republic truly retake this area?
But aren't you winning?
We have more than lawmen to contend with. The Republic have built new machines to cower behind.
These Warden droids have enough firepower to incapacitate a small army.
The rioters are losing hope, but we can reignite their rage. Destroy enough droids and the convicts will smell blood. They'll practically defend our landing zone for us.
When the convicts witness my strength, they'll throw themselves before every droid left standing.
I will set an example.
Crush the warden droids beneath the might of the Force. Inspire the rioters' confidence, and they'll gladly fight our enemy for us.
If a few broken droids will spark the convicts' fury, I'll set this riot ablaze.
I will fuel their anger.
Impress the rioters with your power, and the droids' weakness. Then they'll fight our enemy for us.
Stirring up a riot is dangerous business--and risk demands hazard pay.
I'll do it, but not for free.
Let's hope the convicts learn from your strength and not your mercenary attitude. I could hardly afford to pay them all.
Defeat enough warden droids to inspire the prisoners' confidence. Then they'll fight our enemy for us.
Crowds are so easily manipulated. Once I dispatch the droids, the prisoners will run to follow suit.
I can incite their movement.
Like nerf to the slaughter. Simply defeat enough warden droids to inspire the rioters' confidence. Then they'll fight our enemy for us.
I'm obligated to help.
There's more to this fight than duty. Wreck the warden droids, make it look easy and the rioters will follow your lead.
This place is anarchy as it is. You'll do fine without me.
You handle it. [Refuse quest]
If we must.
Nothing to do? I suppose you could hunt down a few guards.
It won't be my top priority.
